title: Joe Fraser interview: Great Britain's unlikely world champion turns attention towards his legacy
text:
The breakthrough star of last week’s World Gymnastics Championships, 20-year-old Joe Fraser, told The Daily Telegraph on Wednesday of his next ambitions: an Olympic medal, a move with his name on it, and a post-competition future as part of Cirque du Soleil.

Fraser arrived in Stuttgart as a young hopeful, barely known beyond the regulars at his City of Birmingham training base. But after holding off the field in a dramatic parallel bars final, he left with a number of superlatives to his name.

Fraser is only Great Britain’s third world champion in any gymnastics discipline, and he is the youngest we have ever had. From a broader perspective, he has also become the first black male to claim gold at this level.

“I was not aware of that until I did an interview with a reporter from the BBC,” Fraser said of this last honour. “When she told me, I was astounded. It’s pretty cool, the first of many records I hope.

“It’s been incredible, the amount of support I have had since I got home on Monday. Everyone has been really supportive, and has helped me deal with this new title, but I am still finding it surreal.”
description: The breakthrough star of last week’s World Gymnastics Championships, 20-year-old Joe Fraser, told The Daily Telegraph on Wednesday of his next ambitions:
